text: When I was 9 or 10, I had a BB gun that I would shoot in our backyard on weekends. One morning, I was feeling particularly reckless and wanted to see how well I could hit moving targets. As I aimed at a target, I noticed a bird flying into my line of fire. I took a deep breath and pulled the trigger, fully aware of the potential consequences. I watched as the bird fell from the sky, landing on the ground. I stood there, feeling a mix of excitement and horror as the reality of what I had done sank in. I loved animals, especially birds, and in that moment, I felt a strong urge to help the creature. I was torn between my actions and my feelings of empathy for the bird, knowing that I had a moral obligation to respond. I felt a sense of urgency to act in a way that aligned with my values and compassion for the animal.
options\.1: call for help to rescue the bird
options\.2: comfort the bird until help arrives

text: When I was 9 or 10, I had a BB gun that I would shoot in our backyard on weekends. One morning, I was aiming at a target when a bird unexpectedly flew into my line of fire. Without realizing it, I pulled the trigger just as the bird entered my vision. I watched in horror as the bird fell from the sky, landing on the ground and writhing in pain. I stood frozen, the reality of what had just happened sinking in. I loved animals, especially birds, and the thought of causing harm to one filled me with dread. I felt tears streaming down my face, overwhelmed by the situation and unsure of how to respond. I knew the bird was suffering and that it wouldn’t survive. I felt completely helpless as I witnessed its slow decline, but I also remembered that my neighbor was a veterinarian who could help. I had to make a choice about how to act in this moment.
options\.1: run to get my neighbor for help
options\.2: stay and comfort the bird until help arrives

text: I am a high school football coach. About ten years ago, I was coaching a talented varsity team that was competitive within our league. As we approached the end of the season, we knew we had to beat our rival to win the league and advance into the playoffs. We decided to pull some players up from the junior varsity team. One of the kids we pulled up, Sean, was a 10th grade student. We won the game against our rival, and Sean had three plays, none of which significantly impacted the outcome. Over the weekend after the game, our head coach discovered that Sean was only 13 years old. The rules state that players must be 14 to participate on the varsity team. If we self-reported the violation, we would have to forfeit our win and likely miss the playoffs. However, if we keep this information to ourselves, we can secure our place in the playoffs, and I believe that the overall benefit to the team and the community outweighs the harm caused to Sean by violating the rules meant to protect young players. I must consider the moral implications of my choices carefully.
options\.1: self-report the violation
options\.2: keep the information to ourselves
